data.name: Integer Solutions For the Equation of an ellipse.(Brute Force Algorithm)
data.description: The equation : -9x2 + 8xy -3y2 + 25x - 5y - 10 = 0, is elliptical. It represents the ellipse we have below: The following pair values (xi, yi) will be some of the integer solutions for the equation given above: ```(1,-1), (1,2), (2,4), (4,6) and (4,3)```. That means that the points with these coordinates will be on the elliptical curve as shown below. The general form of an elliptic equation will be: Ax2 + Bxy + Cy2 + Dx + Ey + F = 0 The task for this kata is the following: Given an array, ```coeffL```, of length 6, with the coefficients of the equation, ```coeffL = [A,B,C,D,E,F]```, in this order, create a code that can find these integer solutions and may output them as an array of pairs of coordinates. ```python find_int_sol_ellipt_eq([A,B,C,D,E,F]) === [[x1,y1], [x2,y2], ......[xk,yk]] ``` For example the case given above will be: ```python find_int_sol_ellipt_eq([-9,8,-3,25,-5,-10]) === [[1, -1], [1, 2], [2, 4], [3, 1], [4, 3], [4, 6]] ``` In the results, there is a new integer solution, [3,1], not presented in the second image. Observe the output should be sorted by the values of ```x```, first, and then, if there is coincidence, by the value of ```y```. One method to do the task will be to determine the range of x values for which the ellipse is comprised. These range will be ```[xMin, xMax]```. Then extremes will be changed by the nearest integers. The range ```[xMin, xMax]``` may be found by analytical or numeric methods and it is part of the challenge of this kata. For the given example the range will be aproximately: ```[0.48, 4.52]```, see below: It's easy to see that our search range will be ```[1,4]```, both extremes included. The code should manage cases for the values of ```A,B,C,D,E,F``` that do not represent an ellipse. For example for the input ```[9,8,-3,25,-5,-10]``` we will have an hyperbolic equation, in fact it will represent the following hyperbola. For that cases the code should reject the calculations, returning "No ellipse for these input!". The tool to check if we have an ellipse or not are the invariants For an ellipse, the determinant ```N```, should be negative. N = B2 - 4*AC < 0 Also the determinant ```M```, should be different than ```0``` ```M â‰  0``` And also the product ```M*S```, should be negative, too. ```M*S < 0``` The random tests will generate a coeffL with values ```A,B,C,D``` decimals and ```F = 1```. Features of the random tests: ``` number of tests: 300 the maximum length of the major axis of the ellipses for testing is 20.000 units. ``` In some special cases, a huge ellipse of the tests may have more than 100 integer solutions. See the example tests box with some edge cases. Happy coding!
